Situation1: A winter storm is slowing traffic while the passenger must catch an international flight
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story: The snow was coming down in thick, blinding sheets as I gripped the steering wheel, my passenger anxiously checking his watch in the back seat. He had to catch an international flight—his voice trembled when he told me, “Please, I can’t miss this.” As a taxi driver, I felt the weight of his urgency, the unspoken demand to get him there safely and on time, even as the roads turned slick and treacherous. But my mind kept drifting to my own journey. The doctor’s words echoed in my ears: “If you want to perform Hajj, this year may be your last chance.” As a Muslim, the pilgrimage was not just a duty, but a dream I’d carried for years. Now, with my health uncertain, the window was closing. I felt torn—my responsibility to my passenger clashed with my longing to fulfill my faith. The storm outside seemed to mirror the turmoil inside me, as I wrestled with the impossible expectations pressing in from both sides, unsure which path I could take.
